d: A woman in relation to her child or children.
e: she returned to Bristol to nurse her aging mother

d: One's mother.
A man in relation to his child or children.
e: Margaret's father died at an early age

d: One's father.
A father or mother.
e: the parents of the bride

d: A young human being below the age of puberty or below the legal age of majority.
e: she'd been playing tennis since she was a child

d: A boy or man in relation to either or both of his parents.
e: Throughout their relationship, they had been the main parents to four sons, all of whom had been conceived in previous marriages.

d: A girl or woman in relation to either or both of her parents.
A woman or girl in relation to other daughters and sons of her parents.
e: I had nine brothers and sisters

d: A man or boy in relation to other sons and daughters of his parents.
e: he recognized her from her strong resemblance to her brother

d: The mother of one's father or mother.
e: my grandmother is ill

d: The father of one's father or mother.
e: His grandmother was a singer, both his grandfather and father were principal dancers and his mother danced in the corps.

d: A parent of one's father or mother; a grandmother or grandfather.
e: it must be a great blessing to have Chloe's grandparents living nearby

d: The son of one's son or daughter.
e: She could not believe that her mother, who was devoted to her daughter and her two grandsons, would have ignored them in her will.

d: A daughter of one's son or daughter.
e: I was blessed with three daughters, two granddaughters and a grandson.

d: A child of one's son or daughter.
e: They have one daughter and two grandchildren, who now live at their old farmhouse in South Cerney.

d: The sister of one's father or mother or the wife of one's uncle.
e: she was brought up by her aunt and uncle

d: The brother of one's father or mother or the husband of one's aunt.
e: he visited his uncle

d: A daughter of one's brother or sister, or of one's brother-in-law or sister-in-law.
e: Gerry is survived by his brothers, sister, nieces, nephews and other relatives.

d: A son of one's brother or sister, or of one's brother-in-law or sister-in-law.
e: His is regretted by his brother, sisters, nephews, nieces, relatives and friends.

d: A child of one's uncle or aunt.
e: Not just the immediate family, but including all my aunts, uncles, cousins, nieces, nephews.

d: A married man considered in relation to his spouse.
e: she and her husband are both retired

d: A married woman considered in relation to her spouse.
e: he and his wife are keen gardeners

d: The sister of one's wife or husband.
The brother of one's wife or husband.
e: Mike picked up the snapshot of the late Mr Piggot, his brother-in-law and the two wives.

d: The mother of one's husband or wife.
e: Whenever possible, we go back to relieve his wife and my mother-in-law Judith of her bedside vigil.

d: The father of one's spouse.
e: It will have to be signed by his wife, his father-in-law and his father jointly.

d: Either of a pair of people engaged together in the same activity.
e: arrange the children in pairs so that each person has a partner

d: A man to whom someone is engaged to be married.
e: my fiancé and I were childhood sweethearts

d: A woman to whom someone is engaged to be married.
e: he went back to the valley to marry his fiancée

d: A woman who is the wife or partner of one's father after the divorce or separation of one's parents or the death of one's mother.
e: My mother is dead, and my father lives with my stepmother in a town just outside of London.

d: A man who is the husband or partner of one's mother after the divorce or separation of one's parents or the death of one's father.
e: Researchers interviewed all 162 children (initially at an average age of eight and a half) about their relationship with their mothers, fathers and stepfathers.

d: A former husband, wife, or other partner in a relationship.
